intro: Antirrhinum numidicum, commonly known as the Algerian snapdragon, is a flowering plant native to North Africa. It belongs to the Plantaginaceae family and is characterized by its vibrant, tubular flowers that come in shades of red, yellow, and orange. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm and features lance-shaped leaves with a slightly hairy texture. It thrives in well-drained soil and full sun, often found in rocky or arid environments. The flowers are pollinated primarily by bees and other insects, making it an important species for supporting pollinator populations.
